column3:
I think we should aim to get initNetManager()  up as soon as possible, if possible as soon as PaymentServer is created, not postpone it further.

As I see it: The sooner it can process incoming URIs and payment requests and save them up in savedPaymentRequests, the sooner it will no longer launch a new GUI when a new URI is clicked. But I may be wrong...

AFAIK, I think you are wrong here. URIs are pre-processed and stored in `savedPaymentRequests` via `ipcSendCommandLine()`. Which is done early in init. `initNetManager()` on the other hand isn't even used for sending saved requests to a local TCP server (nor is a proxy used for this), but for fetching payment requests from remote servers. So I see no reason to not do it like in this pull. No cons,

I know it is used for receiving requests from remote processes. However, let's say that the user does not have a bitcoin client running then clicks on two bitcoin: URIs in a short timespan. What happens? \nThe first click will start bitcoin-qt adn queue the first URI.\nHowever, the second click will start a second bitcoin-qt, which will continue because there is no server listening yet, and then f
It all depends on `QTimer::singleShot(100, paymentServer, SLOT(uiReady()));` in bitcoin.cpp anyway?\n
I still think this is valuable ;).\n

Agreed; initNetManager does something else than I thought it does

Nit: you can make initNetManager private after this
